title: Former Italy star Fabio Quagliarella opens up on stalker hell after ex-policeman jailed for blackmail and extortion
text:

Former Italy striker Fabio Quagliarella has laid bare his stalker hell. 
Quagliarella, now 34, is still playing in Serie A with Sampdoria and has opened up on the issue which forced him to leave former club Napoli in 2010. 
The forward joined the Partenopei for €18million in 2009, scoring 11 goals in his debut season at the Stadio San Paolo and earning a place in Italy's 2010 World Cup squad. 
But after returning from South Africa, Quagliarella - born in Castellammare di Stabia, situated on the Bay of Naples - surprisingly left his hometown club, joining Juventus on an initial loan deal worth just €4.5million. 
Now, after his stalker - a former policeman - was jailed on Friday for more than four years, Quagliarella has been able to reveal his personal “nightmare," and the reasons behind his departure. Quagliarella played in Italy's ill-fated World Cup campaign in 2010 (Photo: Reuters) Quagliarella celebrates scoring against Cagliari on Sunday (Photo: Getty) Now the veteran hitman is able to put the issue firmly behind him (Photo: Getty) 
Quagliarella was made Sampdoria skipper on Sunday, and scored their goal in the 1-1 draw with Cagliari. 
“This week marked the end of an off the pitch issue that had turned into a nightmare for me,” Quagliarella told Sky Sport Italia , breaking into tears. 
“I have this huge weight taken off my shoulders and this is the real reason I had to leave Napoli and Naples. I was very happy there, but I was affected by this situation that turned into a genuine nightmare. 
“I wouldn’t wish it upon anyone. I couldn’t leave my house, neither could my family. I thank the courts for ensuring the truth came out." Quagliarella is now hoping to move forwards (Photo: Getty) Read More Kostas Mitroglou continues Benfica renaissance with goal of the season contender 
He later told Samp's in-house channel: "Believe me it's a massive weight off my shoulders, said Quagliarella after the game. "Justice has won. I've been through the mill over the past few years. 
"I couldn't speak up for myself because the investigations were ongoing. I've had to deal with terrible things being said about me. 
"This is the start of a second life. A happier one." Quagliarella during his time with Napoli (Photo: Getty) 
In anonymous letters sent to Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis, Quagliarella was accused of cocaine use, having sex with underage girls and links to the Camorra Mafia. 
His stalker, Raffaele Piccolo - a former policeman - had also got in touch with the player, offering to track down the mystery offender in his capacity as an officer of the law. 
Piccolo was sentenced to four years and eight months in prison last Friday, after being found guilty of blackmail and extortion. Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis sold Quagliarella (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Read More Everton loanee Gerard Deulofeu nets first AC Milan goal 
Quagliarella had been forced to testify at Piccolo’s trial last year, where he revealed his belief that the anonymous letters had been behind his sale. 
"Aurelio De Laurentiis sold me because he had received anonymous letters and phone messages accusing me of taking cocaine during house parties with Camorra Mafia members,” reportedly declared the 25-cap Italian at the trial. 
"I was forced to leave my hometown and Napoli sold me to Juventus. I had been falsely accused of being a Camorrist and a paedophile who was participating in orgies." 
Quagliarella's strike against Cagliari was his fifth goal in 25 games in Serie A this season for Samp, following his summer switch from Torino. Like us on Facebook
